surveys.narrative: Crosscut Lake is a small designated stream trout lake that is stocked each spring with yearling brook trout. Conditions are marginal for brook trout in this lake; however, under the current stocking regime anglers can expect to catch brook trout in the summer time that range from 8-12 inches. If winter conditions do not become too severe, and fish carry over into a second season, Crosscut Lake has demonstrated that it can provide a good brook trout fishery and produce some quality size fish.

Crosscut Lake is a designated stream trout lake with an annual stocking of 300 yearling brook trout each spring or early summer. The lake surface area is approximately 11 acres. The lake basin has western and eastern lobes, the western lobe has a maximum depth of 16 feet the eastern lobe has a maximum depth of 6 feet. The brown bog-stained water has scattered beds of aquatic vegetation near shore on mostly muck/detritus substrate. The outlet is a tributary to the Manitou River, a designated trout stream. Access is gained of off U.S. Forest Service Road #172, on unmarked logging roads. Some anglers access the lake from the Tomahawk Snowmobile Trail at the southwest corner of the lake through a carry-in trail down a steep hill.

The special lake assessment on August 26, 2013 profiled the temperature/dissolved oxygen level throughout the water column in the deepest basin of the lake. The depth at the water quality station was 14.5 feet. While this assessment showed unfavorable temperatures and dissolved oxygen levels, Brook Trout are in Crosscut Lake by probably locating small spring fed flowages in the lake that provide thermal and oxygen refuge. The quality of the brook trout fishing in Crosscut Lake varies yearly depending on the length of thermal and oxygen stresses that brook trout undergo.

The brook trout in Crosscut Lake were stocked annually as yearlings. The brook trout numbers have fluctuated widely based on results of the previous investigations. The 2008 sample contained only yearlings from the spring stocking, which measured from 9 inches to 13 inches with the largest 13.2 inches. The brook trout are usually stocked in May so the remainder of the open-water season should provide good trout fishing each year. Winter angling could become difficult as dissolved oxygen levels drop later in the season.

Crosscut Lake has gotten moderate fishing pressure, although the brook trout population has been inconsistent. Brook trout yearlings are stocked annually in this designated stream trout lake. Low dissolved oxygen levels can be a problem in both the winter and summer seasons on Crosscut Lake below the thermocline. Water quality measurements show that fishing should probably be limited to the upper seven feet of water in most cases and if the fishing is slow at that depth move up to four or five feet. Except for the last couple of weeks in October, after the lake has mixed, fishing the bottom of this 16 foot deep lake will rarely be productive.

Crosscut Lake is a 13 acre lake with a maximum depth of 35 feet located approximately 5 miles east of Isabella, MN. To access the lake you need to take USFS Rd #172 (Dumbbell Lake Road) to the Tomahawk Snowmobile Trail, then a foot path down a steep slope to one of the trails on the west shore. This remote lake is lightly fished. Open water angling is most suitable for anglers with a canoe or float tube. Shoreline angling is limited. As Crosscut Lake is a designated trout lake it is important to check the current Minnesota Fishing Regulations to follow all rules applicable to designated trout lakes.

The Brook Trout are stocked annually in Crosscut Lake as yearlings, usually stocking takes place in late May. The re-survey in September 2014 sampled 35 Brook Trout all yearlings from the 2014 spring stocking. The fish averaged 9.6 inches and 0.3 pound; the largest Brook Trout was 12.2 inches (0.9 pound). Crosscut Lake has had a history of low dissolved oxygen levels in the deeper water in late summer. Low dissolved oxygen has been measured in winter investigations also. Anglers fishing Crosscut Lake in summer and winter will want to generally fish shallower than 10 feet, if fishing is slow fish progressively shallower, to target active/feeding fish.

Crosscut Lake is a designated trout lake located five miles east of Isabella that is about 11 acres in size with a maximum depth of 16 feet. Access to the lake is gained by taking Forest Service 172D south from the Wanless Road (FS 172) and left at the Tomahawk snowmobile trail approximately 500 yard to a short foot path down a steep slope to the lake. Shore fishing is limited near the access, although anglers occasionally access other shore fishing areas from the snowmobile trail along the west side of the lake.

The catch from the 2021 fisheries survey consisted of all fish that had been stocked in the spring. Size of trout ranged from 11.2 to 13.4" with an average of about 0.71 pounds. These fish likely grew a small amount while in the lake as the fish stocked in the spring averaged about 0.57 pounds.

The lake is managed for Brook Trout and the current plan calls for catchable sized yearling fish to be stocking annually in the spring. Habitat in the lake is sufficient to support trout through the summer season consistently, but few fish survive the winter. Therefore, the size structure of trout available to anglers during the summer is highly influence by the size of the fish stocked in the spring. The target rate for Brook Trout yearling stocking is about 0.33 pounds per fish, although larger or smaller fish are occasionally produced and distributed.
The lake has a low population of Yellow Perch which may be affected by periodic low oxygen.

No fish were sampled in two gillnets. Repeated attempts to establish a Brook Trout population have not been successful. Anglers have reported catching Brook Trout the summer following the 1987 stocking but netting in 1989 caught no fish from either the 1987 or 1988 stocking. One angler reported to a USFS employee that he caught small Brook Trout in the summer of 1989.

Crosscut Lake is a, small, designated stream trout lake that is stocked with yearling brook trout on a two-out-of-three year rotation. Brook trout were stocked in 2001 and 2002 and will be stocked again in 2004 and 2005.In the summer of 2003 a population assessment was conducted on Crosscut Lake to evaluate the brook trout population. Unfortunately no brook trout were sampled during this assessment, even though recent stockings had occurred. While it is dificult to determine exactly why no brook trout were captured it is suspected that the fish perished during the winter of 2002-2003 due to low oxygen levels. Under normal conditions winterkill does not occur in this lake; however, this past winter had little snow, and cold temperatures resulted in greater ice thickness than would normally occur. This most likely created unsuitable oxygen conditions for brook trout during the long ice covered period.

Crosscut Lake is a remote and scenic designated trout lake located approximately 4 miles east of Isabella, MN. It has an area of 10.7 acres with a maximum depth of 16 feet and has dark brown bog stained water. This remote lake is lightly fished. Open water angling is most suitable from a canoe or float tube. Shoreline angling is limited. Consult the current Minnesota Fishing Regulations for rules applicable to designated trout lakes. Brook Trout are scheduled to be stocked annually as yearlings in Crosscut Lake. To access the lake you need to take USFS Rd. #172 (Wanless Road) to a road through an old clear cut across from the Dumbbell Lake airplane dock leading to the Tomahawk Snowmobile Trail, then a foot path from the trail down a steep slope will bring you to the west shore of the lake. Contact Finland Area office for a detailed access map.

Cold water temperatures and good oxygen levels are essential for Brook Trout growth and survival. To assess these important criteria three continuous temperature loggers were deployed at the deepest point in the lake, suspended at depths of 3, 6, and 10 feet from May 6 to October 25, 2016. Dissolved oxygen checks were conducted throughout the summer at the same location.

The results of this investigation indicated that Crosscut Lake currently maintains suitable water temperatures and dissolved oxygen levels to sustain a stream trout fishery. Temperature and dissolved oxygen will continue to be carefully monitored in future investigations to monitor the suitability of Crosscut Lake for Brook Trout.

Crosscut Lake is a remote and scenic designated trout lake located approximately 4 miles east of Isabella, MN. It is 10.7 acres with a maximum depth of 16 feet. This remote lake is lightly fished. Open water angling is most suitable for anglers with a canoe or float tube. Shoreline angling is limited. Consult the current Minnesota Fishing Regulations to follow all rules applicable to designated trout lakes. Brook Trout are stocked annually in Crosscut Lake as yearlings. To access the lake you need to take USFS Rd #172 (Wanless Road) to a road through an old clear cut across from the Dumbbell Lake airplane dock to the Tomahawk Snowmobile Trail, then a foot path down a steep slope to the west shore. Contact Finland Area office for a detailed map to the lake.

Colder water temperatures and oxygen levels are essential factors in Brook Trout growth and survival. To assess these important criteria three temperature continuous loggers were deployed in the deepest water location in the lake and dissolved oxygen checks were conducted throughout the summer at the same location.

The results of this investigation indicated that Crosscut Lake currently maintains a suitable amount of water temperature and levels of dissolved oxygen to sustain a stream trout fishery within the lake. These parameters will continue to be carefully monitored in future investigations to ensure the suitability of Crosscut Lake for Brook Trout stocking.

Crosscut Lake is a designated stream trout lake that is stocked annually with yearling Brook Trout. A survey was completed in 2020 to monitor the amount of cool, well oxygenated habitat available for trout during the summer. Automated temperature loggers were suspended at depths of two, four, six, and eight feet below the surface over the deepest spot in the lake to record water temperatures hourly throughout the summer. In addition, temperature and dissolved oxygen profiles were collected on several occasions to determine how deep well oxygenated water occurred.

Survey results indicated summer dissolved oxygen concentrations and water temperatures were not limiting factors in Crosscut Lake in 2020. Similar surveys completed in 2015 and 2016 suggest periods of stress are common in summer months, but the lake currently maintains suitable habitat for stream trout throughout the open water season. Habitat conditions will continue to be monitored to evaluate the suitability of Crosscut Lake for stream trout management.
